text.title: Ingo Ruczinski
text.p:
Ingo
Ruczinski
is a Polish professor of
biostatistics
at the
Johns Hopkins Bloomberg
School of Public Health
.

p.s:
Ingo Ruczinski had obtained an M.A. in
mathematics
and
statistics
at the
University at Albany , SUNY
in 1994 .

In 1995 he traveled to Germany where he attended the
University of Würzburg
where he got another M.A. degree , this time in mathematics and
computer science
.

After the completion of M.A. , he returned to the United States where he attended the
University of Washington
from which he graduated with Ph.D. in statistics in 2000 at which he also worked as a teaching assistant at its Department of Statistics ( until 1996 ) , a consultant at the Department of Statistics ( 1998-1999 ) and a research assistant at the Department of Biochemistry ( 1996-2000 ) .
[ 1 ]

In between those positions , Ingo also was a research assistant at the Public Health Sciences of the
Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center
from 1998 to 2000 and then served as its research associate till 2001 .

Upon graduating from the University of Washington , Ingo Ruczinski had became a postdoctoral fellow at the Department of Biochemistry of his alma mater and after half a year of doing it was appointed as an assistant professor at the Department of Biostatistics of the
Johns Hopkins University
at which he served till 2007 .

A year prior to it , he was a member of the Johns Hopkins Institute for Multiscale Modeling of Biological Interactions but in 2008 quit his membership because he was appointed as an associate professor at the Department of Biostatistics of JHU in 2007 .

He also was a visiting professor at the Department of Chemistry at the
University of California , Santa Barbara
between 2003 and 2008 and held the same position at the Centre National de Genotypage in Paris-Evry for one year in 2005 .

Since 2014 , Ingo Ruczinski works as a preceptor at the Johns Hopkins Institute of Genetic Medicine and as a professor at the Department of Biostatistics of the Johns Hopkins University and is also an associate Chair at the Department of Biostatistics of JHU since 2018 .
[ 1 ]

text.p:
As a Chairman , Ingo Ruczinski had been a Session Chair for numerous organizations , including :
American Society of Human Genetics
,
World Health Summit
, International Biometric Conference , Conference on Statistical Methods for Very Large Data Sets , Annual Conference of the International Society for Clininal Biostatistics , Workshop on Statistical and Computational Challenges in Genomics , Symposium on Advances in Genomics , Epidemiology and Statistics .
He also was a Session Organizer of the 2006 and 2007
Eastern North Atlantic Region Meetings , the 2002 , 2005 and 2006
Joint Statistical Meetings
, the International Biometric Conference in 2010 and the Johns Hopkins Biostatistics Centennial Symposium in 2017 , which was dedicated to the opening of the Department of the Biostatistics at the
Johns Hopkins University
in 1877 .
[ 1 ]

p.s:
Besides those positions , Ingo Ruczinski is also known for being a Program Chair of the Section on Risk Analysis at the
American Statistical Association
and had served on a Program Committee of the Joint Statistical Meetings , the Eastern North Atlantic Region , and the
European Conference on Computational Biology
.

In 2014 and 2015 he was an organizer and co-organizer of the honor symposiums for Alan Ross and Tom Louis .
[ 1 ]

Ingo Ruczinski was an associate editor of the
Biometrics
,
BioMed Central Bioinformatics
, and
Biometrical Journal
s and was serving on an editorial board of the
Cancer Prevention Research
.
[ 1 ]

Ingo Ruczinski had also served on numerous reviewing panels , including :
Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development
, the Special Emphasis Panel of the
National Cancer Institute
, Science Unbound Foundation ,
National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research
,
Louisiana Board of Regents
,
Genome Canada
and
Canadian Institutes of Health Research
as well as being a thesis reader at the
Yale School of Public Health
.
[ 1 ]

Ingo Ruczinski had became an elected fellow of the
American Statistical Association
.
[ 2 ]
